opener-hed: We asked thousands of people whether they recognized these hit songs from 1993. We ordered the results by birth year.
opener-subhed: Which song is more likely to be recognized by future generations?

intro-no-diggity.text: I’m obsessed with how future generations will describe music from the 1990s. These will be the songs that our children’s children use to characterize the decade, just as Sinatra or Elvis are emblematic of the 1950s.
The ’90s canon will include generation-defining tracks, such as Blackstreet’s “No Diggity” . This new jack swing standard will unite parents and teens at the weddings and Bar Mitzvahs of the 2050s.

To understand which 1990s songs will enter the canon, we’ll use 2 million data points that I collected via a music quiz, which asked whether readers recognized hundreds of ’90s songs that charted in the top 5 of the Billboard Hot 100.

no-diggity-hed: Here's how well people know “No Diggity,” measured by the percent of people who recognize the song by birth year.

no-diggity-the-sign.text: “No Diggity” knowledge peaks among people who were born in 1985, who were 13 years-old when the song came out in 1998 (i.e., it was on rotation at middle-school dances). We also see a slow drop off among people who were 5 years-old and younger (or not born yet) when “No Diggity” debuted.
That drop-off rate between generations—Millennials to Gen Z—is our indicator for whether “No Diggity” is surviving the test of time.
To make this a bit easier to read, we’ll chart the person’s age at release, rather than birth year.
Here’s another banger from the mid-nineties: “The Sign” by Ace of Base .

chart-text-hed-ace-of-base: Notice the decline in “The Sign” knowledge among people who were 5 years-old when it was released in 1993
chart-text-subhed-ace-of-base: Recognition of “The Sign” by age at the time of its release

scroll-intro.text: For readers who were born much later (i.e., anyone 20 years-old and younger at the time of writing), only half of them recognized “The Sign.”
Millennial readers: this is when you can start feeling old.

You’re probably seeing a trend here: music has a half-life. Songs are less recognizable to people who weren’t around during its prime year of popularity. Find someone 10-15 years your junior, and the likelihood that they’ll know your teenage music references is lower than you think.
How much lower? An easy way to see this is by charting the songs that every millennial knows.

chart-text-hed-scroll: These are songs that were recognized by 90-100% of people who were 13 to 15 years-old when the song debuted.

intro-mean.text: Here we see that Father Time acts indiscriminately: song knowledge erodes with each passing year. This is why I shouldn't be shocked that my Gen Z colleague has never heard “The Sign,” or that teens are filming themselves listening to “Bohemian Rhapsody” for the first time. This is a normal part of the music aging process.
An especially sobering example of this decay is "Wild Wild West" by Will Smith .

wild-west-hed: These are the Millennial hits that are fading at an accelerated rate among Gen Z.
wild-west-sub: Recognition rate of songs by age at time of their release

wild-west.text: In 1999, “Wild Wild West was the song of the summer and pretty much inescapable. Yet it is fading far faster than any other ’90s hit with comparable popularity.

popular.text: Other songs, meanwhile, remain unusually resilient. These are the candidates for ’90s canon.

popular-hed: The ’90s canon: songs that have transcended generations

popular-two.text: Why have these songs transcended their immediate generation? One theory is that they were so remarkably popular and culturally pervasive that they continued to be played. “Jump Around” still gets airplay during timeouts at sporting events. “Macarena” is still a Bar Mitzvah mainstay. “I Will Always Love You” is Whitney Houston’s magnum opus. While there are countless reasons for a song to stay culturally relevant, it's not merely a function of popularity in the year of release.

millennial-only.text: There’s another fascinating subset of music: the songs that are markers of a generation. For example, K-Ci and JoJo’s “All My Life” is known by Millennials but rarely recognized by anyone else. Same thing for Savage Garden’s quintessential teenage love ballad, “Truly Madly Deeply.” These are songs that, in a couple decades, will be lost in time, only recognized by those who were around when the song was in its prime.

lollipop.text: To see how well Millennials and members of Generation Z know other ’90s hits, check out the chart below.

story.text: Here we see that Father Time acts indiscriminately: song knowledge erodes over time [highlight average]. It’s why I shouldn’t be shocked when my Gen-Z colleague mentions that she's never heard “The Sign” by Ace of Base, or that teens are filming themselves listening to “Bohemian Rhapsody” for the first time. This is a normal part of the music aging process, albeit it’s sometimes faster for certain songs.

An especially somber example of this is the fate of “Wild Wild West” by Will Smith. This was the song of the summer in 1999 and pretty much was inescapable, yet it is fading far faster than any other '90s hit with comparable popularity.
Similar to “Wild Wild West”—i.e., songs with a surprising rate decline:
This list also helps us identify the '90s canon: songs that clearly have maintained their popularity and been passed on to the next generation
This list also helps us identify the '90s canon: songs that clearly have maintained their popularity and been passed on to the next generation

You might be thinking: these songs must the cream of the crop; in their prime, they were so mega-popular and pervasive that they bled into Gen Z's cultural knowledge. But remember: Gen Z knows these songs because they continued to be played, either by folks weren't sick of them or because they still had cultural cachet.
“Jump Around” is played during every timeout at sporting events. "Macarena" is still a Bar Mitzvah mainstay. "I Will Always Love You" is Whitney Houston's magnum opus.

The '90s canon question is really interesting on financial terms too. There's a site called Royalty Exchange where you can actually buy rights to a song and reap its royalties. For example, lifetime ownership of Dirty Dancing’s "(I've Had) The Time of My Life" sold for $493,500.
This is what was going through my head when looking at recognition rates: are some songs clearly transcending generations more than we'd expect?
For example, Dr. Dre's "Nuthin' But A G Thang" and Biggie's "Hypnotize" are by no means universally known by Millennials; but look how they've held up versus comparably popular songs.

Based on "Hypnotize's" popularity among Millennials, it should be a lot less popular among 20 year-olds. It's easy to think, "well Hypnotize is a classic, of course it's standing the test of time." Yet, I thought the same thing about plenty of '90s nostalgia that are just fading as we'd expect.
This speaks to, potentially, the broader hip-hop canon: Dr. Dre and Biggie's most well-known songs occupying the burgeoning category of "classic hip hop" on streaming playlists.

Here's another song for the betting market: "Poison" by Bell Biv Devoe. Again, this song is relatively obscure compared to "Baby Got Back," but look how well it's held up versus similarly popular songs.

More obscure hits essentially define Millennials. Here's the average trajectory of "Too Close" by Next, which is recognized by half of Millennials, but its knowledge decayed rapidly for the next generation

At some point, "Too Close" will be a generational marker for Millennials—it's present-day popularity is entirely driven by those who were around during its prime. This would be, in many ways, a terrible song to play at a wedding, as well as a terrible investment on Royalty Exchange.
Here's a number of songs where its knowledge is unique to Millennials
We also noticed that most of Usher's library fits this category
Biggest chance your younger co-worker doesn't know it
